page.title: JavaScript Variables
page.heading: Variables
intro: A variable is a container for storing a value, like a number we can use in a calculation, or a string we might use within a sentence.

content.label: SECTION
copy: To use a variable you've first got to create it, or more accurately, we call this declaring the variable. To do this, we use the keyword var followed by the name you want to call the variable. The name of the variable is often called the identifier.

Here we are creating two variables called myName and myAge. The variables declared have no value; they are empty containers. A variable without any value is an undefined variable. When you enter the variable names in the console, you should get a value of undefined returned.
If the variable does not exist, you'll get an error message.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
copy2: To assign a value to a variable - also known as initializing a value - we use the assignment operator (=). We will not assign values to the two variables declared. When the variable name is used within the console, the value will be returned.

copy2: Unlike some other languages, you don't need to specify what data type (e.g. numbers, strings, arrays, etc) a variable will contain. This is because JavaScript is a 'loosely types language'. For example, if you declare a variable and give it a value within quotes, the browser will treat the variable as a string.
